title: 106_hr2661
content: The Act titled "American Indian Education Foundation Act of 1999" is added to the United States Code, creating the American Indian Education Foundation. The American Indian Education Foundation is a federally chartered charitable and nonprofit corporation with perpetual existence, incorporated in the District of Columbia. It is not an agency or instrumentality of the United States and serves American Indian individuals and Bureau funded schools. The American Indian Education Foundation is a nonprofit corporation incorporated in the District of Columbia. It encourages private gifts for the benefit of the Office of Indian Education Programs and supports educational opportunities for American Indians attending Bureau funded schools. The foundation also collaborates with government entities to further educational opportunities for American Indian students. The American Indian Education Foundation is a nonprofit corporation that supports educational opportunities for American Indians attending Bureau funded schools through a governing body known as the board of directors. The board consists of at least 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior and the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs, who serve as ex officio nonvoting members. Members of the board must be United States citizens knowledgeable or experienced in American Indian education. The board of the American Indian Education Foundation consists of United States citizens knowledgeable in American Indian education, representing diverse viewpoints. Officers include a secretary who serves as the chief operating officer. Board members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The American Indian Education Foundation board members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The foundation has powers to manage property, make contracts, acquire real or personal property, sue and be sued, and perform acts necessary for its purposes. The foundation's principal office is in the District of Columbia, but activities can be conducted throughout the United States. The American Indian Education Foundation has the power to manage property, make contracts, acquire real or personal property, and perform necessary acts. The foundation's offices may be maintained throughout the United States in accordance with its constitution and bylaws. The foundation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents, with board members personally liable only for gross negligence. Administrative costs are limited to 10% of transferred amounts and donations received. Appointment of officers and employees is subject to availability. The American Indian Education Foundation has the power to manage property, make contracts, and acquire real or personal property. The foundation's offices may be maintained throughout the United States. The board members, officers, employees, and agents of the foundation are not considered officers, employees, or agents of the United States. The Secretary of the Interior may transfer funds to the foundation if not prohibited by donation terms. The American Indian Education Foundation, established under SEC. 3, has the power to manage property, make contracts, and acquire real or personal property. The foundation's offices may be maintained throughout the United States. Board members, officers, employees, and agents of the foundation are not considered officers, employees, or agents of the United States. The Secretary of the Interior may transfer funds to the foundation if not prohibited by donation terms. The Secretary of the Interior appoints initial voting members of the board of directors for the American Indian Education Foundation. Successive boards must conform to the foundation's constitution and bylaws. The Secretary provides administrative support for a 5-year period after the enactment of the Act. During a 5-year period after the Act's enactment, the Secretary of the Interior can provide support to the American Indian Education Foundation, including personnel, facilities, and funds for board members' travel expenses. The foundation must reimburse for these services and funds provided. Reimbursements received will be deposited into the Treasury for the costs incurred. The Secretary of the Interior may continue to provide facilities and support services to the foundation after the 5-year period on a reimbursable cost basis.
